tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

The psalmist speaks of Yahweh as if Yahweh were a mountain the people could climb so they would be safe. AT: "the rock where we can go and God will save us." See how "rock" and "of my salvation" are translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:018:046|18:46]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The psalmist speaks as if he is telling the readers to go into the throne room of a king. AT: "go to where he is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"thanking him as we enter his presence"
Possible meanings are that Yahweh is a great king 1) "who rules over all other gods," or 2) "who is much better than all gods."
This is an idiom which means "in his control" or "he is responsible for." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
deep places
high places
The word "hands" is a metonym for Yahweh himself. AT: "he himself formed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
put both knees on the ground, often to show submission (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

The word "pasture" is a metonym for the food that animals eat in the pasture, which in turn is a synecdoche for everything that Yahweh provides for his people. AT: "we are the people whose needs he meets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
an area where animals find grass to eat

The word "hand" here refers to how Yahweh protects his people the way a shepherd protects his sheep. AT: "the people whom he protects like a shepherd protects his sheep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Today—oh, that you would hear his voice!
tn.text: "Oh, that you would hear his voice today!" The psalmist purposely interrupts what he is saying.
Here "his voice" refers to paying attention to God's words. AT: "listen carefully to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Now the writer writes the words that Yahweh spoke.
"become stubborn"
These are places in the desert that Moses named because the Israelites rebelled against God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

These two phrases are both metaphors for the people seeing how much evil they could do before Yahweh would punish them. The phrases say basically the same thing and can be combined. AT: "tested me" or "wanted to see if they could do evil things without my punishing them ... tested whether I would continue to be patient with them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"the amazing things I had done"
Yahweh continues speaking directly to his people.
"40 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"all of those people" or "that entire generation of people"

God speaks of the people as if they were sheep, which will go wherever they want to and not stay near their shepherd. AT: "move away from me" or "go their own way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they have not known my ways
tn.text: "they have not obeyed me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"the way I want them to live"
"the place where I would have allowed them to rest"
